posts.summary: Peacemaker, Jingonhsasee, and Hiawatha
posts.body:
Peacemaker, Jingonhsasee, and Hiawatha

The Great Peacemaker (12th century) was a Native American prophet and political leader. Also called Skén:nen rahá:wi, Deganawida, or Tekanawí:ta, he created the Haudenosaunee (hoe-dee-no-SHOW-nee), a political and cultural union of tribes. His influence resonated for generations and continues to influence American politics today.

Usually said to be miraculously born to a virgin, he was either by birth a member of the Huron or Onondaga tribes, but was adopted into the Mohawk.

At the time, there was warring between tribes. Peacemaker came from the far north and brought peace. His first ally was Jingohsasee, an Iroquoian woman called the Mother of Nations who helped facilitate discussions with leaders. Hiawatha was an Onondaga man (sometimes also said to be adopted into the Mohawk) who was an excellent speaker. Hiawatha helped spread the message (Peacemaker himself apparently had a stutter).

By some legends, Peacemaker climbed a tree and had it be chopped down, whereupon he fell into the river. All thought he had drowned, but the next morning he was well and sitting near a campfire. This was a sign of his moral purity and spirituality.

These three were the founders of the Haudenosaunee, also called the Iroquois Confederacy, and brought together the five nations: the Mohawk, the Oneida, the Onondaga, the Cayuga, and the Seneca. (Today, it also contains the Tuscarora Nation–it joined around 1722 after forced displacement from what is now the Carolinas.)

It is absolutely certain, but often underemphasized, that the democratic style of government that survived for centuries with the Haudenosaunee was integral in the writing of the US Constitution–both George Washington and Ben Franklin were known to have admired the Confederacy.

While some components of these stories cannot be proven, historians are certain that these three people existed and forged a new style of democratic government.

posts.summary: Ljuba Prenner
posts.body:
Ljuba Prenner

An outspoken and determined lawyer and author, Ljuba Prenner (1906-1977) was a brilliant Yugoslavian and a trans man.

[Prenner in 1967]

Prenner was AFAB (assigned female at birth) but transitioned as a teenager. He went to law school at the University of King Alexander I and began publishing short stories and novels, often detective stories.

After completing his doctorate, Prenner opened a law practice and defended people against the state. He was a member of the Osvobodilna fronta (Liberation Front, an anti-fascist civil resistance movement) where he hosted meetings and housed comrades. He also provided legal advice and defense to detainees and prisoners. He worked with political prisoners and was imprisoned several times himself. Sent to pre-trial jail at the Ferdeng Women’s Camp, he helped the other prisoners file complaints about the poor food and sexual assaults, and often received time in solitary confinement.

Prenner never stayed imprisoned for long–he was an excellent lawyer who represented his clients well and was known for winning difficult cases. His political actions resulted in him being expelled from the Slovene Writers’ Association and got his law license revoked, then reinstated.

Prenner was a trans man whose status was known to his family, his country, his colleagues, and the woman who was his partner for years.

posts.summary: Things That Weren't Invented/Discovered By White People: Art Edition
posts.body:
Things That Weren’t Invented/Discovered By White People: Art Edition

  1. Abstract Art: Abstract art was used by nearly all societies of North and South America. European art societies called it primitive and not worth consideration until the 1890s, when it served as inspiration for the modern American abstract art movement.
  2. Comic Books: The first comic books were kibyōshi, mass-produced picture books starting in 1775, in Edo-period Japan. They were social satires about urban life and included commentaries on governmental corruption and class struggle.
  3. Art That Could Be Seen From Space: Nazca Lines are geoglyphs in the Peruvian desert. They were created between 500 BCE and 500 CE. Beautiful works of art that can only be truly appreciated from a view that humans did not have, they are often assumed to be for the gods. There are hundreds of Nazca Lines.

[pictured: a Nazca Line shaped like a cat]

posts.summary: A black dragón floating above the clouds
posts.caption:
the-tzimisce:

themediocrehuman:

catsoverloaded:

A black dragón floating above the clouds

So others need not squint to read

“On March 11, 889 CE, 17 year-old Emperor Uda wrote: 

‘On the 6th day of the 2nd Month of the First Year of the Kampo era. Taking a moment of my free time, I wish to express my joy of the cat. It arrived by boat as a gift to the late Emperor, received from the hands of Minamoto no Kuwasahi. 

The color of its fur is peerless. None could find the words to describe it, although one said it was reminiscent of the deepest ink. It has an air about it, similar to Kanno. Its length is 5 sun, and its height is 6 sun. I affixed a bow about its neck, but it did not remain for long.

In rebellion, it narrows its eyes and extends its needles. It shows its back.

When it lies down, it curls in a circle like a coin. you cannot see its feet. It’s as if it were a circular Bi disk. When it stands, its cry expresses profound loneliness, like a black dragon floating above the clouds.

By nature, it stalks birds. It lowers its head and works its tail. It can extend its spine to raise its height by at least 2 sun. Its color allows it to disappear at night. I am convinced it is superior to all other cats.’”

“[list of traits common to many or all cats] I am convinced it is superior to all other cats” is the cat owner’s creed

history can be sweet sometimes, too.

posts.summary: Yoshiko Kawashima
posts.body:
Yoshiko Kawashima

A complex historical figure, Yoshiko Kawashima (1907-1948) was a Chinese princess-turned spy for the Japanese Empire.

n.b. Most articles on Kawashima use she/her pronouns. This post will use they/them. I don’t believe it’s any more or less correct than she or he (gender identity is a social construct, and it does not easily translate across decades, cultures, and languages), but will emphasize Kawashima’s personal choices.

[Kawashima]

Born Aisin Gioro Xianyu in Beijing to the imperial clan of the Qing dynasty, the Xinhai Revolution of 1912 resulted in Kawashima being adopted by their father’s friend, a Japanese mercenary. Kawashima was raised and educated in Japan.

In 1925, they said they “…decided to cease being a woman forever.” because “I was born with what the doctors call a tendency toward the third sex, and so I cannot pursue an ordinary woman’s goals in life… Since I was young I’ve been dying to do the things that boys do.” As a child, even before transition, Kawashima acted and spoke in a masculine fashion, but after this, they dressed and acted as a man.

Two years later, Kawashima was married to a Mongolian man. They were divorced after three years, and Kawashima moved to Tokyo, where they had a number of both male and female lovers.

Kawashima began working as a spy for imperial Japan during the Second Sino-Japanese War. They worked undercover in Manchuria, usually as a man, occasionally as a woman. They led a band of 3,000 cavalrymen as a counterinsurgency force.

Over time, this story became popular in Japan and Kawashima became well-known, enough so that their ability to go undercover was compromised. Kawashima also started to criticize the Japanese military and its policies in Manchukuo, so they were not effective in propaganda.

After the end of the war, Kawashima was arrested, tried, and executed by China for treason.

It’s an interesting story. The comment about the ‘tendency toward the third sex’–was Kawashima intersex or tomboyish? Were they a gender non-conforming woman, a trans man, or nonbinary? Are any of these post-Stonewall English terms applicable to Kawashima’s situation at all? How we talk about queer figures of the past is important, but it is often an unsolvable puzzle. If Kawashima is alive today, with our current language, we cannot say for sure how they would call themself.

reblog.comment:
Yoshiko Kawashima

A complex historical figure, Yoshiko Kawashima (1907-1948) was a Chinese princess-turned spy for the Japanese Empire.

n.b. Most articles on Kawashima use she/her pronouns. This post will use they/them. I don’t believe it’s any more or less correct than she or he (gender identity is a social construct, and it does not easily translate across decades, cultures, and languages), but will emphasize Kawashima’s personal choices.

[Kawashima]

Born Aisin Gioro Xianyu in Beijing to the imperial clan of the Qing dynasty, the Xinhai Revolution of 1912 resulted in Kawashima being adopted by their father’s friend, a Japanese mercenary. Kawashima was raised and educated in Japan.

In 1925, they said they “…decided to cease being a woman forever.” because “I was born with what the doctors call a tendency toward the third sex, and so I cannot pursue an ordinary woman’s goals in life… Since I was young I’ve been dying to do the things that boys do.” As a child, even before transition, Kawashima acted and spoke in a masculine fashion, but after this, they dressed and acted as a man.

Two years later, Kawashima was married to a Mongolian man. They were divorced after three years, and Kawashima moved to Tokyo, where they had a number of both male and female lovers.

Kawashima began working as a spy for imperial Japan during the Second Sino-Japanese War. They worked undercover in Manchuria, usually as a man, occasionally as a woman. They led a band of 3,000 cavalrymen as a counterinsurgency force.

Over time, this story became popular in Japan and Kawashima became well-known, enough so that their ability to go undercover was compromised. Kawashima also started to criticize the Japanese military and its policies in Manchukuo, so they were not effective in propaganda.

After the end of the war, Kawashima was arrested, tried, and executed by China for treason.

posts.summary: Things That Weren't Invented/Discovered By White People
posts.body:
Things That Weren’t Invented/Discovered By White People

  1. Electroplating: The Moche of Peru developed electroplating using chemically-generated electricity to gild copper with cold. They developed this around 500 CE, a thousand years before Europeans (independently) invented the same process.
  2. Freeze-drying: Andean civilization developed a unique technique to freeze-dry and dehydrate food since the 1200s CE. The process involved multiple cycles of exposing food to freezing temperatures on top of mountains at night, then squeezing them and putting them in the sun during the day. This allowed them to store food for years and transport it across the Inca Empire.
  3. Public Opinion Polling: The first nationwide poll to determine public opinion was done by Korean King Sejong the Great in 1430 CE to determine fairness in a new proposed tax system.
  4. Parental Leave: Sejong the Great also enacted a series of laws giving new parents both maternity and paternity leave.

posts.summary: On This Day In History
posts.body:
On This Day In History

October 8th, 1969: The opening rally of the Days of Rage occurs, organized by the Weather Underground in Chicago. This was a student demonstration to end American involvement in the Vietnam War, resulting in 287 arrests.

“The Elections Don’t Mean Shit—Vote Where the Power Is—Our Power Is In The Street”.

posts.summary: The Mirabal sisters
posts.body:
The Mirabal sisters

Las Hermanas Mirabal were revolutionary women in the Dominican Republic.

Usually known as Patria (1924-1960), Minerva (1925-1960), and María Teresa (1926-1960), the Mirabal sisters spoke out again the dictator Rafael Trujillo, nicknamed El Jefe. A fourth sister, Dedé (1925-2014) worked to tell their story.

In 1949, Minerva first met Trujillo, where she turn downed his sexual advances and was subsequently jailed and, for fear of her safety, prevented from attending law school for six years. She did eventually attend the University of Santo Domingo, where she graduated summa cum laude as the first woman to graduate from law school in the Dominican Republic.

This helped her and her sisters’ interest in politics–and their hatred of the dictator (started years before, when Trujillo murdered their friend for political opposition). It was Minerva who first became involved against Trujillo, but first María Teresa and then Patria joined after witnessing the atrocities of the regime.

Their group, the 14th of June Movement, educated citizens about Trujillo’s crimes and gathered weapons. They were discovered, and Minerva and María Teresa were jailed, as were the husbands of all three women.

On November 25th, 1960, Patria, Minerva, and María Teresa were stopped by Trujillo’s agents, where they were strangled and then clubbed to death. Multiple sources have since confessed this assassination was by direct order of Trujillo himself.

After this, Dedé Mirabal devoted the rest of her life to tell the story of her sisters and raising the children they had left behind. They have been recognized internationally as a symbol of social justice and feminism, and bravely standing against oppressive regimes. November 25th is now the International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women, in remembrance of their assassination.

tags: History They Didn't Teach You In School
posts.summary: History They Didn't Teach You In School
posts.body:
History They Didn’t Teach You In School

The Anti-Vagrancy Act (Greaser Act) of 1855 was a law implemented in California designed to restrict the movement of Mexicans.

Following the end of the Mexican-American War in 1848 and the accompanying Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo, the United States acquired land it would split into Wyoming, Utah, Texas, New Mexico, Nevada, Colorado, and California. In order the solidify White power in their new land, the government passed a number of racist laws.

The Act made legal the arrest of persons who were ‘vagrants’, people including those unemployed, prostitutes, and “Greasers…who go armed and are not peaceable and quiet persons.” (Section 2) This was a derogatory term for those of “Spanish and Indian blood”, so it specifically targets the Mexicans who already lived on the land that had suddenly changed hands.

This law served to criminalize ethnic minority groups doing everyday behavior and, though the prison system, force them into unpaid labor. It also allowed for extra-legal “justice”, authorizing local militias to terrorize Mexicans, confiscate their property, and seize their land.

For more White supremacist laws passed in the same time period, consider the Chinese Exclusion Act (1882) and the Foreign Miners’ Tax (1850). Also consider “An Act for the Government and Protection of Indians” (1950), a similar anti-vagrancy law that was much stricter, against Native Americans in California.

posts.summary: Things That Weren't Invented/Discovered By White People: Warfare
posts.body:
Things That Weren’t Invented/Discovered By White People: Warfare

  1. Bullet-proof vests: Mesoamericans wore a form of unspun cotton armor called an ichcahuipilli, which was both much lighter and much more effective than chainmail armor. Though originally designed to stop darts and arrows, it was also effective against musket shots. It was unique in that it could actually stop musket shots, rather than attempting to make them glance off to the slide like European armor did. Invading Spanish quickly chose ichcahuipilli over their inferior metal armor.
  2. Gunpowder: The earliest known chemical explosive was used in many things, including celebrations and warfare. One of China’s Four Great Inventions, it was actually developed by Taoists as a form of medicine.
  3. Portable firearms: Egyptian portable hand cannons called midfa were the first handguns, used by Egyptians to repel invading Mongols at the Battle of Ain Jalut in 1260. They also fireproofed their clothes using dissolved talc powder.

  1. Bullet-proof vests: Mesoamericans wore a form of unspun cotton armor called an ichcahuipilli, which was both much lighter and much more effective than chainmail armor. Though originally designed to stop darts and arrows, it was also effective against musket shots. It was unique in that it could actually stop musket shots, rather than attempting to make them glance off to the slide like European armor did. Invading Spanish quickly chose ichcahuipilli over their inferior metal armor.
  2. Gunpowder: The earliest known chemical explosive was used in many things, including celebrations and warfare. One of China’s Four Great Inventions, it was actually developed by Taoists as a form of medicine.
  3. Portable firearms: Egyptian portable hand cannons called midfa were the first handguns, used by Egyptians to repel invading Mongols at the Battle of Ain Jalut in 1260. They also fireproofed their clothes using dissolved talc powder.

posts.summary: Ángela Jiménez
posts.body:
Ángela Jiménez

Ángela Jiménez (1896-1990) was a soldadera, a warrior woman in the Mexican Revolution. Born to a Zapotec mother and a Spanish father, Ángela Jiménez fought openly as a woman.

In 1911, she saw Spanish Federals invade her hope and attempt to rape her sister, but her sister shot the officer with his own gun. After this, Ángela Jiménez swore to fight and kill as many federals as she could.

She began dressing as a man called Angel and joined the Revolution, alongside her father. It was known that she was a woman, and she reached the position of lieutenant despite this.

As a revolutionary, she was a soldier and a leader. She was also an explosives expert and worked in espionage, wearing a woman’s dress to gather information and escape prison and executioner.

When general Amaro banned soldaderas in 1925, she spoke out against him. She was a loud voice for woman’s rights in Mexico and, when she immigrated to Texas, in the United States.

posts.summary: Things That Weren't Invented/Discovered By White People
posts.body:
Things That Weren’t Invented/Discovered By White People

  1. Rubber balls: The Mesoamerican Olmecs first produced rubber balls around 1700 BCE. They played a game called ōllamalīztli with a rubber ball that could weigh up to 4kg|9lb. A related, modern version of this game called ulama is still played.
  2. Bunk beds: The first bunk beds were used in Iroquoian longhouses, where several families would live in one house together. As a useful space-saving technique, they are now widely used.
  3. Hammocks: Hammocks were commonly used in indigenous peoples from the Caribbean islands, as well and South and Central America. When the Spaniards first made contact, they began using hammocks as sleeping places on boats because of how they are more comfortable on ships, and this was eventually adopted by all of Europe.

posts.summary: Things That Weren't Invented/Discovered By White People: Food Edition
posts.body:
Things That Weren’t Invented/Discovered By White People: Food Edition

  1. Noodles: The first evidence of noodles show they existed 4,000 years ago in China. These were at least partially made of millet. This recipe spread to Japan as well.
  2. Maize: Interestingly, it can be said that maize was invented by indigenous Mesoamerican peoples more than it was discovered or domesticated. Its natural ancestor was teosinte grasses, but it was the result of careful breeding and deliberate artificial selection. Human intervention is required for corn to propagate, it could not exist on its own in the wild. Corn quickly spread up and down the Americans from its origin point in what is now Mexico. It is perhaps the single most important crop in the world today, accounting for more production than any other grain and a staple of cuisines around the world.
  3. Jerky: A method of preserving meat before refrigeration, jerky was invented by indigenous Andeans. The word ‘jerky’ is an Anglicization of the Quecha word ch'arki which was a staple for Inca travelers using the famous Incan road system. In fact, the Inca Empire was able to make llama ch'arki with a freeze-drying process in the 16th century!

posts.summary: Valentina Ramírez Avitia
posts.body:
Valentina Ramírez Avitia

Valentina Ramírez Avitia (1893-1979) was a Mexican revolutionary. Sometimes called “The Mexican Mulan”, she dressed as a man to be allowed to fight against the Spanish Empire.

Avitia was born in the town of Norotol, in the northwest of Mexico. Her father had been killed early in the Mexican Revolution. Inspired by him, Avitia enlisted in her brother’s clothes under the name Juan Ramírez.

She was a successful soldier in the Maderista Army and quickly rose to the rank of lieutenant. However, in under 6 months, she was discovered and dismissed from the army.

After this, she was shunned from her family and from society, living on her own and begging. Today we can give her the honor she should have gotten from the beginning–she was a brave heroine and an inspiration who deserved to have her actions known and celebrated.

posts.summary: Pope Benedict the 9th
posts.body:
Pope Benedict the 9th

A short story today about my favorite pope! Pope Benedict IX, born Theophylactus of Tusculum (1012-1056) was the head of the Catholic Church three separate times!

The nephew of the Pope before him, Benedict IX first became Pope at age 20 through egregious bribery. He was incredibly unpopular and scandalous, and was the first pope in history rumored to be gay. This resulted in a revolt, and he was driven out of his post, and out of Rome. Pope Sylvester III succeeded him.

This lasted for a few months before Benedict IX returned to expel Sylvester III, and became pope again.

Then Benedict IX abdicated, and sold the seat of the papacy to his godfather, Pope Gregory VI. Benedict is the only man to have ever sold the papacy in history.

He changed his mind and returned to depose his godfather. Gregory VI and Sylvester III also insisted they were still the Pope, and all three excommunicated each other.

Then the Germans, finding the whole thing annoying, crossed the mountains into Italy with an army and elected Clement II the new pope.

Benedict IX is on the Wikipedia list of “sexually active popes.”

posts.summary: Things That Weren't Invented/Discovered By White People: Medicine Edition (Part 2)
posts.body:
Things That Weren’t Invented/Discovered By White People: Medicine Edition (Part 2)

  1. Anesthetics and Topical Pain Relievers: Many cultures made use of anesthetics in their medical practices, including ancient Egypt, India, and China. However, the anesthetic use by Native Americans, both as ingestible and topical medications, was incredibly effective, due in part to the incredibly wide variety of known pain relievers, each used for a different purpose.
  2. Syringes: The first hypodermic needles and syringes were invented and used for medical reasons by Native Americans.
  3. Eating Vitamin C to Prevent Scurvy: Hundreds of years before English ‘limeys’ figured out how to prevent scurvy on long voyages, this was common knowledge in the Inca Empire of South America.

posts.summary: Things That Weren't Invented/Discovered By White People: Math Edition
posts.body:
Things That Weren’t Invented/Discovered By White People: Math Edition

  1. Math: A lot of history texts will first mention math in terms of the Greeks, but math is a means of understanding the world. The first human mathematicians were ancient Africans from at least 35,000 BCE, as evidenced by mathematical artifacts like the Lebombo bone and the Ishango bone.
  2. The Number Zero: The number zero is immensely important to do any form of advanced math. The first math sometimes had a placeholder value (like the zero in ‘10’), but the numerical quantity zero was invented only twice in all of human history. It appeared the Mesoamerican Olmecs (the civilization the predates the Maya) likely before the 4th century BCE. in India in the 7th century CE (and maybe as early as the 5th century).
  3. The Pythagorean Theorem: Named after a Greek mathematician, the equation relating sides of a right triangle (a2 + b2 = c2) was in use in the First Babylonian Empire, now Iraq and Syria, over a thousand years earlier, around the 16th century BCE.

posts.summary: Things That Weren't Invented/Discovered By White People: Medicine Edition (Part 1)
posts.body:
Things That Weren’t Invented/Discovered By White People: Medicine Edition (Part 1)

  1. Inoculation: Edward Jenner’s experiment with milkmaids and smallpox (1796) is considered the first case of medical inoculation against infectious diseases in the West. However, China had been using variolation to inoculate against smallpox in the 1500s (and some sources claim as early as the 200BCE).
  2. Antibiotics: Many would say that Alexander Fleming discovered antibiotics when he isolated penicillin in 1928. However, Nubians were drinking beer that contained the antibiotic tetracycline as early as 350 CE.
  3. Smoking is Dangerous: Texts from Timbuktu relate the harmful effects of smoking tobacco centuries before it began medical proven in the West.

posts.summary: Dolores Huerta
posts.body:
Dolores Huerta

Hispanic Heritage Month is half over, and we turn to Dolores Clara Fernández Huerta (b. 1930), a Mexican-American labor leader and civil rights activist.

Born in New Mexico and raised by her mother in Stockton, California, Huerta faced racial discrimination in her childhood. She attended Stockton College for a provisional teaching credential and taught elementary school, before leaving her job to begin focusing on activism.

She co-founded the Stock Chapter of the Community Service Organization, the Agricultural Workers Association, and the National Farm Workers Association. She helped refocus on farmworkers, seeing them as the poorest members of society with no rights and no recourse when being mistreated.

Huerta directed the boycott on the Delano grape strike, one of the biggest strikes in American history that successfully ended in the entire California table grape industry signing a collective bargaining agreement.

She has also supported laws such as letting people take the driver’s test in Spanish and repealing the Bracero Program.

Huerta has been arrested twenty-two times for participating in non-violent civil disobedience. She serves on the boards of the People for the American Way, the Consumer Federation of California, and the Feminist Majority Foundation. Huerta campaigns to help Latines and women get elected to public office.

Huerta supports labor rights, civil rights, immigrant rights, women’s rights, and LGBTQ rights, and has been fighting for intersectionality since the 60s. In 2021, Huerta received the Presidential Medal of Freedom. April 10th is Dolores Huerta Day in California. and Washington State.

posts.summary: Things That Weren't Invented/Discovered By White People: Scientific and Mathematical Theories Edition
posts.body:
Things That Weren’t Invented/Discovered By White People: Scientific and Mathematical Theories Edition

  1. Heliocentrism: the astronomical model in which the Earth and other planets revolve around the Sun. We typically learn that it was invented by Copernicus and/or Galileo in the 16th century CE; in reality, heliocentrism is mentioned in the Aitareya Brahmana, an ancient Indian text c. 600 BCE.
  2. Atomism: the theory that the world is composed of fundamental indivisible components. While the Greeks did independently come up with this theory in the 5th century BCE, Indian philosophy worked with atomic theory as early as the 9th century BCE.
  3. Algebra: the study and manipulation of mathematical symbols. The title of “The Father of Algebra” had also previously gone to a Greek named Diophantus. However, a Persian man named Muhammad ibn Mūsā al-Khwārizmī (last name also sometimes transliterated as Algorithmi, so you see where the names for ‘algebra’ and 'algorithm’ come from) was the first to treat algebra as an independent discipline (rather than associated with geometry).

posts.summary: Frida Kahlo
posts.body:
Frida Kahlo

Halfway through Hispanic Heritage Month, it’s time to talk about Frida Kahlo. Magdalena Carmen Frida Kahlo y Calderón (1907-1954) was a Mexican painter and a badass. A communist, a disabled, bisexual woman of color, and one of the greatest artists in human history, it’s no wonder that Kahlo’s work is known around the world.

[“The Frame” by Frida Kahlo. 1938]

Kahlo was disabled by polio as a child and then was in a bus accident, effectively ending her aspirations to go to medical school (which had very recently opened its doors to women), Kahlo began to paint herself while recovering in bed, sometimes using a harness around her head to help her look at her easel.

[“Self-Portrait with Thorn Necklace and Hummingbird” by Frida Kahlo. 1940]

She quickly grew in talent and fame, and traveled international to the United States and Europe to put on exhibitions. She also taught students at the Escuela Nacional de Pintura, Escultura, y Grabado.

[“Me and My Parrots” by Frida Kahlo. 1941]

Her paintings death with wellness and disability, politics, self, death, Mexican identity, gender, class, and postcolonialism. Her art style is Surrealist and Magical Realist. She was the first Mexican artist to be featured in the Louvre, and is an icon in Chicano, feminist, and queer history.

[“Marxism Will Give Health to the Sick” by Frida Kahlo. 1954]

tags: National Day for Truth and Reconciliation
posts.summary: Today, September 30th, is the annual Orange Shirt Day (National Day for Truth and Reconciliation). An observance day to promote...
posts.body:
Today, September 30th, is the annual Orange Shirt Day (National Day for Truth and Reconciliation). An observance day to promote awareness about the residential school system in Canada and the continuing effects of cultural genocide, people are encouraged to wear orange shirts and educate themselves on the history of residential schools.

I have some links below that are not hyperlinked, copy and paste into your browser to learn more.

CANADA
[orangeshirtday.org]
[legacyofhope.ca]
[https://indigenouspeoplesatlasofcanada.ca/article/history-of-residential-schools/]

UNITED STATES
[https://boardingschoolhealing.org/education/us-indian-boarding-school-history/]
[http://www.nativepartnership.org/site/PageServer?pagename=airc_hist_boardingschools]
[https://www.npr.org/sections/codeswitch/2021/08/28/1031398120/native-boarding-schools-repatriation-remains-carlisle]

AUSTRALIA
[https://aiatsis.gov.au/explore/stolen-generations]

NEW ZEALAND
[https://thespinoff.co.nz/atea/14-11-2017/our-stolen-generation-a-shameful-legacy/]
[https://interactive.aljazeera.com/aje/2017/quite-genocide/index.html]

SCANDANAVIA
[https://www.rcinet.ca/eye-on-the-arctic/2016/02/10/sami-abused-in-swedens-church-run-schools/]
[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/arts/awards-and-festivals/tiff/sami-blood-shines-spotlight-on-assimilation-of-indigenous-children-in-scandinavia/article31892290/]

A UN report [https://www.un.org/esa/socdev/unpfii/documents/IPS_Boarding_Schools.pdf] also mentions residential schools in the following countries that had the goal of prioritizing colonizing language, values, and practices. I’m looking for writing from or interviews with affected people to link.
-Peru
-Mexico
-Venezuela
-Colombia
-Brazil
-Russia
-Vietnam
-China
-India
-Malaysia
-Palestine
-Oman
-Iran
-Kenya
-Djibouti
-Eritrea
-Botswana
-Sierra Leone
-Ghana

posts.summary: Carlos Juan Finlay
posts.body:
Carlos Juan Finlay

A Cuban epidemiologist, Carlos Juan Finlay (1833-1915) was a pioneer in yellow fever research who had to fight for his ideas to be taken seriously at all–before finally being vindicated decades later.

“The confirmation of Dr. Finlay’s doctrine is the greatest step forward made in medical science since Jenner’s discovery of the vaccination.”

-Dr. Leonard Wood

Finlay attended Jefferson Medical College in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, where he was first introduced to the germ theory of disease (miasma theory would remain the premiere explanation of infection for decades) and returned to Havana to practice.

In 1881, he became the first person to correctly identify the mosquito as a carrier for yellow fever and explained the pest control could help disease control. [Many stories report he was literally laughed at when presented his findings, but this story appears to be apocryphal.]

It still took 20 years for Finlay’s ideas to be proven beyond doubt. They contributed to the eradication of yellow fever in Cuba, and Finlay was appointed the chief sanitation officer of Cuba.
